title: Radiosity (radiometry)
text:
In <a href="radiometry">radiometry</a>, radiosity is the <a href="radiant%20flux">radiant flux</a> leaving (emitted, reflected and transmitted by) a surface per unit area, and spectral radiosity is the radiosity of a surface per unit <a href="frequency">frequency</a> or <a href="wavelength">wavelength</a>, depending on whether the <a href="Spectral%20radiometric%20quantity">spectrum</a> is taken as a function of frequency or of wavelength. The <a href="International%20System%20of%20Units">SI unit</a> of radiosity is the <a href="watt">watt</a> per square metre (), while that of spectral radiosity in frequency is the watt per square metre per <a href="hertz">hertz</a> (W·m−2·Hz−1) and that of spectral radiosity in wavelength is the watt per square metre per metre (W·m−3)—commonly the watt per square metre per nanometre (). The <a href="Centimetre%E2%80%93gram%E2%80%93second%20system%20of%20units">CGS unit</a> <a href="erg">erg</a> per square centimeter per second () is often used in <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a>. Radiosity is often called in branches of physics other than radiometry, but in radiometry this usage leads to confusion with <a href="radiant%20intensity">radiant intensity</a>.

Likewise, "M"e,"i"° − "J"e,"i" is the blackbody exitance minus the radiosity and serves as the 'potential difference'. These quantities are formulated to resemble those from an <a href="Network%20analysis%20%28electrical%20circuits%29">electrical circuit</a> "V" = "IR".

Because the above is "between" surfaces, "R""ij" is the resistance of the space between the surfaces and "J"e,"i" − "J"e,"j" serves as the potential difference.
Combining the surface elements and space elements, a circuit is formed. The heat transfer is found by using the appropriate potential difference and <a href="Resistor%23Series%20and%20parallel%20resistors">equivalent resistances</a>, similar to the process used in analyzing <a href="Network%20analysis%20%28electrical%20circuits%29">electrical circuits</a>.
Other methods.
In the radiosity method and circuit analogy, several assumptions were made to simplify the model. The most significant is that the surface is a diffuse emitter. In such a case, the radiosity does not depend on the angle of incidence of reflecting radiation and this information is lost on a <a href="Diffuse%20reflection">diffuse</a> surface. In reality, however, the radiosity will have a <a href="Specular%20reflection">specular</a> component from the reflected <a href="radiation">radiation</a>. So, the heat transfer between two surfaces relies on both the <a href="view%20factor">view factor</a> and the angle of reflected radiation.
It was also assumed that the surface is a gray body, that is to say its emissivity is independent of radiation frequency or wavelength. However, if the range of radiation spectrum is large, this will not be the case. In such an application, the radiosity must be calculated spectrally and then <a href="Integral">integrated</a> over the range of radiation spectrum.
Yet another assumption is that the surface is <a href="Contour%20line">isothermal</a>. If it is not, then the radiosity will vary as a function of position along the surface. However, this problem is solved by simply subdividing the surface into smaller elements until the desired accuracy is obtained.
